FacilityName: Archer Daniels Midland Co. Decatur Complex
SafetyInspectionBy: State of Illinois - State Fire Marshall

_prev_prog_3.Description:
The ADM Corn Processing facility (1000059961 and 1000060744) is located within the ADM Decatur complex and utilizes "Natural Gasoline" containing pentanes (n-pentane and iso-pentane, both a "flammable chemical") is used to denature ethyl alcohol prior to being stored for load-out.  The facility (1000059961 and 1000060744) has a hazard prevention program for the process.  The facility?s program is a Process Safety Management (PSM) program which addresses the Prevention Program 3 requirements of 40 CFR ?68.175.  The program covers distillation, blending, and storage of ethyl alcohol, including natural gasoline storage.  All safeguards described in this section (e.g., process controls, mitigation systems, monitoring/detection systems) apply to the anhydrous ammonia system at the Corn Processing facility (1000059961 and 1000060744).  



Plant Manager: Steve Merritt

Date of Emergency Response Plan Review/Update: 12/18/2014

Date of Emergency Response Plan Training for employees: 8/18/2014

Last Safety Inspection by External Agency: 2/7/2013

Name of Agency: OSHA

The ADM BioProducts facility is located within the ADM Decatur Complex and stores anhydrous ammonia in two processes: 1) Storage Tanks (1000060175) and 2) railcars (1000060240).  The facility has one prevention program for both processes.  The facility?s program is a Process Safety Management (PSM) Program which addresses the Prevention Program 3 requirements of 40 CFR ?68.175.  All safeguards described in this section (e.g. process controls, mitigation systems, monitoring/detection systems) apply to the anhydrous ammonia storage tanks and related equipment, which also includes railcar unloading.



Plant Manager:  Mike Pasquariello

Date of Emergency Response Plan Review/Update: 4/23/2015

Date of Emergency Response Plan Training for employees: 12/31/2014

Last Safety Inspection by External Agency: 1/15/2015

_prev_prog_3.Description:
The ADM Cogeneration facility is located within the ADM Decatur complex and utilizes anhydrous ammonia for the reduction of emissions of nitrous oxides. The anhydrous ammonia is received from the ADM BioProducts facility (1000060175 and 1000060240) The facility has a hazard prevention program for the process. The facility?s program is a Process Safety Management (PSM) Program which addresses the Prevention Program 3 requirements of 40 CFR ?68.175.   All safeguards described in this section (e.g., process controls, mitigation systems, monitoring/detection systems) apply to the anhydrous ammonia system at the Cogeneration facility.  



Plant Manager: Troy Lancaster

Date of Emergency Response Plan Review/Update: 7/15/2014

Date of Emergency Response Plan Training for employees: 1/31/2015

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Hydrogen plant process piping and vessels
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The ADM Glycols facility (1000060629) is located within the ADM Decatur Complex and produces hydrogen by the steam reforming of desulfurized natural gas. Hydrogen is purified and stored in a low pressure storage tank before it is sent to compressors. Low pressure hydrogen is also piped to the Corn Plant (1000060744 and 1000059961) low pressure storage tank.  High pressure hydrogen is stored in high pressure storage tanks and is piped from these tanks to the glycols production area.  High pressure hydrogen is also piped to the Corn Plant (1000060744 and 1000059961) high pressure storage tanks. Hydrogen enters the hydrogen discharge pipe header which is connected to two reactor trains in which it reacts with glycerin over a catalyst to produce glycols. The Glycols facility (1000060629) has a hazard prevention program for the process.  The facility?s program is a Process Safety Management (PSM) Program which addresses the Prevention Program 3 requirements of 40 CFR ?68.175. The program covers hydrogenolysis, hydrogen production, compression, and storage. All safeguards described in this section (e.g., process controls, mitigation systems, monitoring/detection systems) apply to the hydrogen systems at the Glycols Plant.



Plant Manager: Michael Kruley

Date of Emergency Response Plan Review/Update: 7/25/2014

Date of Emergency Response Plan Training for employees: 9/14/2014

Last Safety Inspection by External Agency: 7/22/2014

Name of Agency: Illinois Environmental Protection Agency

The Corn Processing facility (1000060744 and 1000059961) is located within the ADM Decatur Complex and utilizes hydrogen for the production of sorbitol. Hydrogen is produced at the West Refinery (1000060746) and Glycols (1000060629) and is piped to the Corn Plant (1000060744 and 1000059961) low pressure storage tanks from each facility. Compressors at the Corn Processing facility (1000060744) are used to produce high pressure hydrogen. The Glycols facility (1000060629) and Corn Processing facility (1000060744 and 1000059961) also share a high pressure hydrogen pipeline between high pressure storage tanks at each respective location. High pressure hydrogen is reacted with dextrose over a catalyst to produce sorbitol. The facility has a hazard prevention program for the process.  The Corn Processing facility?s (1000060744 and 1000059961) program is a Process Safety Management (PSM) Program which addresses the Prevention Program 3 requirements of 40 CFR ?68.175. The program covers reactor operation, hydrogen compression, and storage. All safeguards described in this section (e.g., process controls, mitigation systems, monitoring/detection systems) apply to the hydrogen systems at Corn Processing (1000060744 and 1000059961).



Plant Manager: Steve Merritt

Date of Emergency Response Plan Review/Update: 12/18/2014

Date of Emergency Response Plan Training for employees: 8/18/2014

Last Safety Inspection by External Agency: 2/7/2013

Name of Agency: OSHA

_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: 11256- Hydrogen System Flange Inspection; 11257 - East Hydrogen Compressor; 11259 - Hydrogen Instrumentation; 2100018809 - Hydrogen tower Tank Thickness Testing
_prev_prog_3.Description:
The ADM Vitamin E facility (1000060745) is located within the ADM Decatur Complex and receives low pressure hydrogen from the West Refinery (1000060746). The Vitamin E facility (1000060745) then uses compressors to increase the hydrogen pressure to high pressure. The high pressure hydrogen is piped to four reactors in which it reacts with the non-alpha tocopherol to produce alpha tocopherol. The Vitamin E facility (1000060745) has a Process Safety Management (PSM) program which address the Prevention Program 3 requirements of 40 CFR ?68.175. The program covers reactor operation, hydrogen compression, and storage. All safeguards described in this section (e.g., process controls, mitigation systems, monitoring/detection system) apply to the hydrogen system at the Vitamin E facility (1000060745).



Plant Manager: Matt Philips

Date of Emergency Response Plan Review/Update: 12/22/2014

Date of Emergency Response Plan Training for employees: 12/16/2014

Last Safety Inspection by External Agency: 12/16/2014

Name of Agency: Global Risk

The West Refinery (1000060746) is located within the ADM Decatur Complex and produces hydrogen by steam reforming of desulfurized natural gas at three separate hydrogen plants.  Hydrogen is purified and stored in low pressure storage tanks.  Hydrogen is piped to the hydrogenation area in which it reacts with vegetable oil over a catalyst to produce hydrogenated vegetable oil.  The facility also transfers low pressure hydrogen via pipeline to the Vitamin E (1000060745) and the Corn Processing facility (1000060744 and 1000059961). The facility has a Process Safety Management (PSM) Program which addresses the Prevention Program 3 requirements of 40 CFR ?68.175. The program covers the hydrogenation process, hydrogen production, and storage. All safeguards described in this section (e.g., process controls, mitigation systems, monitoring/detection systems) apply to the hydrogen systems at the West Plant Refinery.



Plant Manager: John Barry/Brad Birkholtz

Date of Emergency Response Plan Review/Update: 2/25/15

Date of Emergency Response Plan Training for employees: 2/25/15

Last Safety Inspection by External Agency: 4/21/2015

Name of Agency: State of Illinois Fire Marshall

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
This Risk Management Plan (RMP) has been prepared for the ADM Decatur Complex.    The Decatur Complex is an industrial complex with contiguous and adjacent facilities consisting of an East Complex and a West Complex, as well as additional support facilities.  The following locations are covered by this RMP:  Corn Processing, BioProducts, East Plant, Glycols, and Cogeneration within the East Complex and Vitamin E and the West Soybean Refinery Facility within the West Complex.

  

Each listed location employs chemical specific safety precautions in handling hazardous chemicals to reduce the threat to workers, members of the community and the environment.    Emergency response for the ADM Decatur Complex is coordinated with ADM Personnel and the Decatur Fire Department.   Each location has its own emergency response plan and prevention program.  In addition, within the response plans, each location has developed chemical specific response strategies applicable to their location. The plans also include procedures for notifying the appropriate personnel and agencies in the event of an accident involving a hazardous chemical.  The Emergency Response Plan review and training dates listed in Section 9 of this RMP are based upon the most recent plan reviews and training dates conducted within the Decatur Complex.  The most recent review of the Emergency Response Plan was conducted by the BioProducts facility on April 23, 2015. The most recent Emergency Response Plan training was conducted at the West Refinery on February 25, 2015.   The most recent safety inspection within the complex was conducted at the West Refinery on 4/21/2015, by the State of Illinois-Office of the State Fire Marshall. 



This plan addresses the following three chemicals: 



1)    Anhydrous Ammonia -   BioProducts and Cogeneration 

Anhydrous ammonia is received by truck and rail and stored in three storage tanks.  At the BioProducts facility, anhydrous ammonia is used as a pH control and a nitrogen so

urce for product fermentation. At the ADM Cogeneration facility, anhydrous ammonia is utilized to reduce emissions of nitrous oxides.   



2)    Pentane - Corn Processing 

"Natural Gasoline" containing pentanes (n-pentane and iso-pentane, both a "flammable chemical") is used to denature ethyl alcohol prior to being stored for load-out.  



3)    Hydrogen - Corn Processing, Glycols, West Plant Refinery and Vitamin E

Hydrogen is produced at the Glycols and West Refinery plants. It is used at Glycols to produce propylene glycol. It is used at the West Refinery to hydrogenate vegetable oil. The Corn Processing facility utilizes hydrogen to produce sorbitol. The Vitamin E Plant uses hydrogen to produce Alpha tocopherol from non-Alpha tocopherols. All plants store hydrogen. Glycols, Corn Processing, and Vitamin E use compressors to increase the pressure of hydrogen which is required for each of their processes. The Corn Processing facility and the Glycols facility share a low pressure hydrogen pipeline between locations and as well as a high pressure pipeline.





The Prevention Program Descriptions for each covered process provide information related to the prevention program details, emergency response plan reviews and training at the specified location.  The key concepts of ADM's prevention programs are the elements of each location's site specific Process Safety Management (PSM) program. Each location's emergency response plans are coordinated with ADM personnel and/or the Decatur Fire Department, such that, in the event of an accident/incident, immediate emergency response measures can be implemented.  ADM works cooperatively with the Decatur Fire Department to improve response capabilities.  



In the past five years, the ADM facilities listed above have not experienced any accidents/incidents involving the referenced covered processes that have required reporting under this standard.  



ADM personnel focus on safety on a daily basis.  General safety planning and

improvement programs are also in place through various safety committees and management activities at each location.  The locations continue to evaluate options for improving processes and efficiencies in order to reduce the quantities of hazardous materials used and stored at its facilities.  In addition, ADM also continually evaluates options at its facilities for replacing hazardous materials with less hazardous or non-hazardous materials.  Continued safe operations are a result of the following:  precautions used in handling hazardous chemicals, personnel training, and the engineering of inherent safety features in the design of equipment.
